column1: The city is popular for being a pilgrimage site. It prides itself as the "Pilgrimage Capital of the Philippines". The Marian image of the Our Lady of Peace and Good Voyage or the Virgin of Antipolo
column2: which was brought in from Mexico in 1626
column3: and enshrined in the Antipolo Cathedral has a continuous following among Filipino Catholics since the Spanish colonial era. A popular custom of pilgrimages to the Virgin of Antipolo is the trek going to its shrine on the eves of Good Friday and May 1
column4: from various locations in Rizal Province and Metro Manila. The most notable of these pilgrimages would begin the trek from the Minor Basilica of the Black Nazarene (Quiapo Church)
column5: in Quiapo
column6: Manila following the procession of the image. There is also an existing custom to have new cars blessed at the church in the belief that this will ensure the safety of the car and its passengers
column7: and also preferred by outgoing OFWs to ensure their success in abroad.Its higher elevation than that of Metro Manila affords it a scenic view of the metropolis
column8: especially at night. Its locally grown mangoes and cashews are popular among tourists
column9: as well as suman – a local delicacy made out of glutinous rice. The Hinulugang Taktak National Park
column10: which was once a popular summer get-away is being restored to become again one of the city's primary attractions because it was devastated by a typhoon.

column3: President Rodrigo Duterte signed Republic Act 11475
column4: a law transferring the capital and seat of government of the province of Rizal from Pasig City to Antipolo. The law will effect 15 days after the official publication in newspaper of general circulation or in the Official Gazette. The official publication is June 22
column5: 2020 and took effect on July 7
column6: 2020. From 1901 up to that year Pasig City served as the de jure capital of the province of Rizal. But in 1975
column7: it became part of Metro Manila and the capital and the seat of government remained in Pasig until 2009 when the Provincial Capitol was transferred to Antipolo with the new buildings as mentioned.

column1: Antipolo is in the northern half of Rizal Province
column2: close to its meridional center. It is located on the slopes of the Sierra Madre Mountain Range. Much of the city sits on a plateau averaging 200 meters. It has the second-largest city area in the province
column3: with an area of 156.68 km². The northern and southern sections of the city are in the dense forest areas of the Sierra Madre.Antipolo is landlocked; it is bounded to the north by San Mateo and Rodriguez
column4: to the east by Tanay
column5: to the south by Angono
column7: and to the west by Cainta and Marikina City in Metro Manila.

column6: with the church's fortress-like "campanilla" (belfry) serving as a watchtower against Spanish defenders sailing from the walled city of Intramuros via the Pasig River.

column1: Antipolo is politically divided into 16 barangays. The area where the boundaries of Barangays Dela Paz
column2: San Isidro
column3: San Jose and San Roque meet is the city proper or locally referred to as bayan.

column1: Antipolo's population in the 2015 census was enumerated at 776
column2: 386 inhabitants. It grew at an annual rate of 4.19 percent from the 2000 figure. Annual population growth rate has slowed relatively remains above the annual national average of 2.04 percent. The 2007 figure is three times the population of the city in 1990.

column1: Residents of the city are mainly Tagalogs. Very minor communities of the indigenous Dumagat people are found in Barangay Calawis and sitios Old Boso-Boso
column2: San Isidro
column3: San Jose and Kaysakat in Barangay San Jose.

column1: Similar to other cities in the Philippines
column2: the government structure of Antipolo is prescribed in the Local Government Code of 1991
column3: and further codified in its city charter. It is headed by a city mayor
column4: who serves as its chief executive and exercises overall supervision of its administrative agencies.

column2: the city vice mayor
column3: primarily serves as presiding officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod and assumes the position of city mayor in the event of its vacancy. As presiding officer of the Sangguniang Panlungsod
column4: the vice mayor does not vote except in cases to break a tie.

column1: The city's Sangguniang Panlungsod or city council is composed of 16 elected members
column2: two ex officio officers and an option to have at most three sectoral representatives. The 16 barangays Antipolo is divided into are grouped into two districts. Each of these districts elect at-large eight city councilors
column3: while the two ex officio officers are the city's Liga ng mga Barangay president and Sangguniang Kabataan Federation president.

column2: it also reviews the ordinances enacted by its barangays and makes recommendations for modification if they are found to be inconsistent with existing laws and city ordinances. On the other hand
column3: ordinances and certain resolutions of the Sangguniang Panlungsod are transmitted to the Sangguniang Panlalawigan of Rizal for compliance review.

column1: Elective city officials serve a term of three years and may serve up to three consecutive terms.
Antipolo's barangays are grouped into two legislative districts. Each district elects a representative each to the Sangguniang Panlalawigan and the House of Representatives.
Antipolo is classified as a First Class City as of last local government income classification of the Department of Finance in 2008.   In 2007
column2: the city registered a total revenue of ₱993.1 million
column3: an increase of 5.6 percent from the previous fiscal year; in 2010 this amount has grown to ₱1.56 billion. Its proximity to Metro Manila has continuously spurred the growth of the real estate industry and by 2007
column4: revenue from real property taxes has ballooned by 32.1 percent from 2006 to ₱146.2 million as there are also about 456 residential subdivisions in the city.

column1: The Department of Education maintains a school division in Antipolo
column2: which supervises the 65 public schools (45 elementary schools
column3: 20 high schools) in addition to 193 accredited private schools.

column1: There are three universities/college operating satellite campuses in the city
column2: the state-run University of Rizal System
column3: De La Salle College of Saint Benilde and Our Lady of Fatima University.
